questions.text: The patient, 37 years old, has symptoms of light-headedness. The patient is saying that he is feeling dizzy while even taking a walk. He can't specify his symptoms properly. Also, there are complaints of episodic dizziness upon changing his position. As a doctor what is your next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dix Hallpike maneuver This is a patient who has dizziness which can describe a variety of common sensations that include vertigo, lightheadedness, faintness and imbalance. The patient has symptoms of Episodic dizziness on changing position point towards a diagnosis of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo ( when head position changes, gravity causes the otoconia to move within the canal, producing vertigo and nystagmus ) which can be diagnosed on Dix Hallpike maneuver.

Highyeild:

Dix Hallpike maneuver- All patients with episodic dizziness, especially if provoked by positional change, should be tested with the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Step 1- The patient begins in a sitting position with the head turned 45 degrees. Step 2- Holding the back of the head, the examiner then lowers the patient into a supine position with the head extended backwards by about 20 degrees while watching the eyes. Step 3-Posterior canal BPPV can be diagnosed confidently if transient up beating-torsional nystagmus is seen. Step 4- If no nystagmus is observed after 15–20 s , the patient is raised to the sitting position. Step 5- The procedure is repeated with the head turned to the other side. Frenzel goggles may improve the sensitivity of the test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Check for eye movements Particular focus is given to checking eye movements . However, when there is the presence of episodic dizziness on changing his position, the Dix Hallpike maneuver should be performed. Option B. Head impulse test This test can identify both unilateral and bilateral vestibular hypofunction. However, when there is the presence of episodic dizziness on changing his position, the Dix Hallpike maneuver should be performed. Dynamic visual acuity testing This test is a functional test that is used for assessing vestibular function . However, when there is the presence of episodic dizziness on changing his position, the Dix Hallpike maneuver should be performed.

Extraedge:

Modified Epley maneuver - for treatment of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo of the right (top panels) left (bottom panels) posterior semicircular canals . Step 1. With the patient seated , turn the head 45 degrees toward the affected ear. Step 2 . Keeping the head turned, lower the patient to the head-hanging position and hold for at least 30 s and until the nystagmus disappears. Step 3. Without lifting the head, turn it 90 degrees toward the other side . Hold for another 30 s. Step 4. Rotate the patient onto her side while turning the head another 90 degrees , so that the nose is pointed down 45 degrees . Hold again for 30 s. Step 5. Have the patient sit up on the side of the table . After a brief rest , the maneuver should be repeated to confirm successful treatment.

questions.text: A 28 yrs male complains of acute onset dizziness on suddenly getting up from a supine position. On examination, there is the presence of torsional upward beating nystagmus. The following maneuver was performed on the patient. All of the following are true about this except

options.label: A
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus is never possible for this patient

options.label: B
options.text: This maneuver is commonly performed for posterior canal BPPV

options.label: C
options.text: The attack is due to calcium carbonate crystals

options.label: D
options.text: Nystagmus commonly beats upwards and torsionally

questions.correct_answer: A. Horizontal nystagmus is never possible for this patient
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Horizontal nystagmus is never possible for this patient This option is false because, less commonly the otoconia can enter the horizontal canal , resulting in horizontal nystagmus when the patient is lying with either ear down The patient has acute onset dizziness on changing position and torsional upward beating nystagmus on examination point towards a diagnosis of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo(BPPV) and the maneuver performed on this patient for treatment of BPPV is Epley’s maneuver. In BPPV →head position changes→ gravity → otoconia to move within the canal→ vertigo and nystagmus.

Highyeild:

Modified Epley maneuver - for treatment of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo of the right (top panels) left (bottom panels) posterior semicircular canals . Step 1. With the patient seated , turn the head 45 degrees toward the affected ear. Step 2 . Keeping the head turned, lower the patient to the head-hanging position and hold for at least 30 s and until the nystagmus disappears. Step 3. Without lifting the head, turn it 90 degrees toward the other side . Hold for another 30 s. Step 4. Rotate the patient onto her side while turning the head another 90 degrees , so that the nose is pointed down 45 degrees . Hold again for 30 s. Step 5. Have the patient sit up on the side of the table . After a brief rest , the maneuver should be repeated to confirm successful treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. This maneuver is commonly performed for posterior canal BPPV -This option is true because the Epley maneuver is commonly performed for posterior canal BPPV. Option C. The attack is due to calcium carbonate crystals- This option is true because the attacks are caused by free-floating otoconia(calcium carbonate crystals) that have been dislodged from the utricular macula and have moved into one of the semicircular canals, usually the posterior canal. Option D.Nystagmus commonly beats upwards and torsionally- This option is true because in the posterior canal BPPV (Most common) when head position changes → gravity causes the otoconia to move within the canal→ Nystagmus beats upward and torsionally (the upper poles of the eye beat towards the affected lower ear ).

Extraedge:

Dix Hallpike maneuver- All patients with episodic dizziness, especially if provoked by positional change, should be tested with the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Step 1- The patient begins in a sitting position with the head turned 45 degrees. Step 2- Holding the back of the head, the examiner then lowers the patient into a supine position with the head extended backwards by about 20 degrees while watching the eyes. Step 3-Posterior canal BPPV can be diagnosed confidently if transient up beating-torsional nystagmus is seen. Step 4- If no nystagmus is observed after 15–20 s , the patient is raised to the sitting position. Step 5- The procedure is repeated with the head turned to the other side. Frenzel goggles may improve the sensitivity of the test.

questions.text: Which semicircular canal is tested in a caloric test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral Caloric testing compares the responses of the two horizontal /Lateral semicircular canals .

Highyeild:

Caloric testing- This test stimulates your acoustic nerve by delivering cold or warm water or air into your ear canal . Checks Vestibular apparatus integrity. Negative Caloric testing indicates a problem in the Brainstem. When cold water or air enters your ear →the inner ear changes temperature→it should cause fast, side-to-side eye movements called nystagmus. Procedure: Check if the tympanic membrane is intact. One ear is tested at a time. A small amount of cold water (30 degrees) or air is gently delivered into one of your ears. The eyes should show an involuntary movement called nystagmus. Then they should turn away from that ear and slowly back. A small amount of warm water(44 degrees) or air is gently delivered into the same ear. Again, Eyes should show nystagmus. Then they should turn toward the same ear and slowly back. Another ear is tested in the same way.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are not the correct choices.

questions.text: A patient presents to medicine OPD with complaints of sudden onset of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus and a sense of pressure in the involved ear. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ménière’s disease The patient has Sudden onset vertigo, tinnitus and a sense of pressure in the ear all these symptoms are characteristic of Ménière’s disease (Endolymphatic hydrops)

Highyeild:

Ménière’s disease Ménière’s disease is associated with excess endolymph fluid in the inner ear; hence the term endolymphatic hydrops . The exact pathophysiological mechanism, however, remains unclear. Clinical features- Vertigo hearing loss Pain, pressure, and/or fullness in the affected ear Low-frequency hearing loss Audiometry at the time of an attack - asymmetric low-frequency hearing loss hearing commonly improves between attacks although permanent hearing loss may eventually occur. Treatment- Diuretics Sodium restrictions If attacks persist- Injections of glucocorticoids or gentamicin into the middle ear Non Ablative surgical decompression and shunting of the endolymphatic sac. Full ablative procedures vestibular nerve section Labyrinthectomy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Benign paroxysmal positional Vertigo - It is characterized by vertigo lasting for a few sec-min on changing head position. Option C.Vestibular neuronitis-Severe vertigo of sudden onset with no cochlear symptoms. Attacks may last from a few days to 2 or 3 weeks . It is thought to occur due to a virus that attacks the vestibular ganglion (following viral infection-Upper Respiratory tract infection). Option D. Acoustic neuroma - It has been classified as a peripheral vestibular disorder as it arises from CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus. It causes Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and loss of corneal reflex ( Most common ). Severe episodic vertigo , as seen in the end-organ disease, is usually missing .

questions.text: A patient presents to medicine OPD with complaints of intermittent vertigo, and fluctuating SNHL which occurs while coughing and lifting heavy weights. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perilymph fistula The patient has intermittent vertigo , and fluctuating SNHL which occurs while coughing and lifting heavy weights( Raised ICP ) pointing towards a diagnosis of Perilymphatic fistula.

Highyeild:

Perilymphatic fistula- Perilymph leaks into the middle ear through the oval or round window . Etiology- A complication of stapedectomy Ear surgery when stapes are accidentally dislocated Sudden pressure changes in the middle ear Barotrauma Diving Forceful Valsalva Raised intracranial pressure Weightlifting vigorous coughing Clinical features- Intermittent vertigo Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss Tinnitus sense of fullness in the ear.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Benign paroxysmal positional Vertigo - It is characterised by vertigo lasting for a few sec-min on changing head position. Option C. Basilar migraine- is a vascular syndrome producing recurrent headaches with symptom-free inter- vals. Headache is usually unilatera l and of the throbbing type. Basilar artery migraine produces occipital headache, visual disturbances, diplopia and severe vertigo which is abrupt and may last for 5–60 min. Option D. Acoustic neuroma - It has been classified as peripheral vestibular disorder as it arises from CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus. It causes Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and loss of corneal reflex ( Most common ). Severe episodic vertigo , as seen in the end-organ disease, is usually missing .
